title: Tough decision to sit local kid Paul Byron
text:
Ottawa Senators 
Paul Byron was denied a chance to play for his new team in his hometown Sunday, but the decision was a tough one for his coach. 
Addressing the media before his Habs took the ice to face the Senators in their home opener, Michel Therrien passionately explained why he left Byron -- an Ottawa native plucked off waivers from the Flames when Zach Kassian was put into a substance abuse program -- off the roster. 
"He's not in (the lineup) and it's breaking my heart because he's a kid (and) I heard a lot of good things (about him)," he said, conjuring up memories of an interview two seasons ago when, regarding a Brian Gionta injury that would keep him out of the Montreal lineup injury, Therrien explained that "our captain was crying in my arms" over the news. 
"He's got a lot of energy," Therrien continued on Byron. "Our plan was to play him, especially (because) he's from here. But I got to be honest with the guys I got, the guys on the fourth line. (Bryan) Flynn, (Torrey) Mitchell and Devante Smith-Pelly ... they did a great job (int he first two games), they worked hard, so I have no reason to take them out of the lineup. 
"This is what I told Paul this morning: 'I wish I played you, I know you're from here. I'm going to need time. I got to be honest with the rest of the players.' Eventually, he'll get a chance. In the meantime, he's got to be a little patient." 
A diminutive forward who starred for the Gatineau Olympiques when Claude Giroux was also on the team, Byron has played 138 NHL games -- eight for Buffalo and the rest with Calgary -- during which he has scored 17 goals and 31 assists.
